metadata.title: Synthesis and thermal properties of the MA/HDPE composites with nano-additives as form-stable PCM with improved thermal conductivity

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Applied Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/ locate/apenergy
Synthesis and thermal properties of the MA/HDPE composites with nano-additives as form-stable PCM with improved thermal conductivity
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apenergy.2016.07.106 0306-2619/ 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: gyfang@nju.edu.cn (G. Fang).
Yaojie Tang, Di Su, Xiang Huang, Guruprasad Alva, Lingkun Liu, Guiyin Fang ⇑ School of Physics, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, China
h i g h l i g h t s
MA/HDPE composites with nano-additives were prepared for thermal conductivity enhancement. Microstructure and chemical structure of the FSPCM were analyzed. Thermal properties and thermal reliability of the FSPCM were investigated. Thermal conductivity of the FSPCM can be enhanced by adding NAO and NG.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 8 April 2016 Received in revised form 17 July 2016 Accepted 25 July 2016
Keywords: Form–stable phase change materials Myristic acid/HDPE composite Nano–Al2O3 Nano–graphite Thermal properties Thermal conductivity
a b s t r a c t
For the purpose of improving the thermal conductivity of the form–stable phase change materials (FSPCM), two types of nano–powders with high thermal conductivity were added into the samples. In the modified FSPCM, myristic acid (MA) was used as a solid–liquid phase change material (PCM), high density polyethylene (HDPE) acted as supporting material to prevent the leakage of the melted MA. Nano–Al2O3 (NAO) and nano–graphite (NG) were the additives for thermal conductivity enhancement. Scanning electronic microscope (SEM), Fourier transformation infrared spectroscope (FT–IR) and X-ray diffractometer (XRD) were used to analyze the microstructure, chemical structure and crystalline phase of the samples, respectively. Furthermore, the specific latent heat and phase transition temperature, thermal conductivity and thermal reliability were investigated using differential scanning calorimeter (DSC), thermal conductivity meter and thermo–gravimetric analyzer (TGA). The results showed that the MA was uniformly absorbed in the HDPE matrices and there was no leakage during the melting process when the mass fraction of the MA in the MA/HDPE composite was less than 70%. The DSC results revealed that the modified FSPCM have a constant phase change temperature and high specific latent heat. The thermal conductivity of the FSPCM was measured in the solid (30 C) and liquid (60 C) states of the MA. When the mass fraction of nano–powder additives is 12%, the thermal conductivities of the FSPCM increase by 95% (NAO) and 121% (NG) at 30 C. It is anticipated that the FSPCM possess a potential application for thermal energy storage.
2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The growing greenhouse gas emissions into atmosphere and resource constraints are driving all spheres of mankind to improve the utilization of energy. Thermal energy storage system is a technology of storing thermal energy in thermal reservoirs for later use. The charging process of the thermal energy storage system is usually set at off–peak time. Then, the thermal energy storage system releases thermal energy in peak time. Therefore, these systems
will use less energy during peak time, which can improve system’s efficiency, such as building heat preservation [1–3] and solar water heat [4], which are usually time dependent. The thermal energy storage system can store and release energy in the forms of sensible heat, latent heat and reversible thermochemical reaction for energy redistribution [5]. Latent heat storage based on the PCM plays an important role among the thermal energy storage system owing to the advantages of high enthalpy change and stable chemical structure. In addition, the temperature of the PCM remains almost the same not only during phase change process but also from storage to release [6]. The PCM involves four states of phase change: solid–solid, solid–liquid, gas–solid and gas–liquid [7]. But only the
Nomenclature
tpeak temperature of maximum thermal degradation rate ( C) DHC latent heat of the composites (kJ/kg) DH0 latent heat of pure materials (kJ/kg) DW percentage of the mass loss
Greek letters x mass fraction of nano-additives g mass fraction of the myristic acid in the composites k thermal conductivity of the modified FSPCM
Abbreviations DSC differential scanning calorimeter
FSPCM form-stable phase change materials FT-IR Fourier transformation infrared spectroscope HDPE high density polyethylene MA myristic acid MEPCM micro-encapsulated phase change materials NAO nano-Al2O3 NG nano-graphite PCM phase change materials SEM scanning electronic microscope TGA thermo-gravimetric analyzer XRD X-ray diffractometer
solid–liquid variety can be used for practical application because the other varieties have technical limitation [8]. The solid–liquid PCM is usually categorized into organic PCM, inorganic PCM and their eutectics [9]. In recent decades, a variety of fatty acids belonging to organic PCMwere investigated and used for practical application [10–12] because they are economically affordable and wildly available, non–toxic and have low subcooling degree [13]. Therefore, the MA as a typical fatty acid was employed in this work.
However, in order to store and release the latent thermal energy, special encapsulation storage devices are used for containing the organic PCM and prevent the leakage of the traditional organic PCM. This will result in the increase of thermal resistance and associated cost [14]. In recent years, developing micro–encapsulated phase change material (MEPCM) and form–stable phase change materials (FSPCM) is a popular solution to overcome the defect above [15,16]. The MEPCM and FSPCM can keep the shape of the PCM in the solid state even when environment temperature is over the melting point of the organic PCM. High volume change, large supercooling, complicated synthesis technology and high cost of the MEPCM are primary limiting factors for its thermal energy storage application in comparison with the FSPCM, although the MEPCM can encapsulate the organic PCM and increase the thermal transfer area [17]. The FSPCM are synthesized by absorbing the organic PCM into supporting materials [18], including organic polymers (high density polyethylene [19], polymethyl methacrylate [20], eudragit [21], poly (vinyl chloride) [22], etc.) and inorganic porous materials (activate carbon [23], expanded perlite [24], diatomite [25], etc.). Polyethylene has the characteristics of acid and alkali resistance, organic solvent resistance and excellent electrical insulation, and can maintain some tenacity at low temperature, which make it a greatly suitable matrix for the FSPCM. The FSPCM paraffin wax/polyethylene is typical organic PCM/polymers composites and was investigated by respectable scholars. Molefi et al. [26] compared the influence of wax content on thermal and tensile properties of different polyethylene/paraffin wax blends. The result showed that the blends were immiscible and the melting temperatures of wax and all polyethylene were reduced in the FSPCM. Meanwhile, the presence of wax caused a reduction in tensile properties. Chen and Wolcott [27] studied the leakage of polyethylene/paraffin binary composites and the result indicated that the co–continuous structure was the main cause for the paraffin leakage by using morphological and chloroform extraction methods and crystal perfection of the high density polyethylene (HDPE) performed better than the low density polyethylene and linear low density polyethylene in the blends.
In some situation, high thermal conductivity is necessary to accelerate the phase change process of the thermal energy storage system for storing and releasing thermal energy, and low thermal
conductivity is precisely one of the primary disadvantages of the FSPCM, especially organic PCM/polymers composites. Different solutions were investigated to enhance the thermal conductivity [8,28,29], and adding additives with high thermal conductivity to the FSPCM is one popular and efficient method to overcome this defect. Zhang et al. [30] studied the influence of different additives on thermal conductivity of the FSPCM. The result revealed that the thermal conductivity of the FSPCM could be increased greatly by adding exfoliated graphite and an empirical was developed for predicting the practical thermal conductivity of the FSPCMwith different mass fraction of the graphite. Cheng et al. [31] enhanced the heat conduction of shape–stabilized paraffin/HDPE composites by adding graphite powder and expanded graphite. The result showed that the addition of the expanded graphite enhanced the thermal conductivity of the composite significantly from 0.31 W (m K) 1 to 1.36 W (m K) 1 when the mass fraction of the expanded graphite is 4.6%.
Nano–additives with extremely high thermal conductivity are potential additives to improve the thermal conductivity of the PCM. The emerging materials like nanostructure–based colloidal suspensions for thermal energy storage were studied extensively for thermal conductivity enhancement since 2005 [32]. Nourani et al. [33] added NAO stabilized by sodium stearoyl lactylate into paraffin composite. The result showed that effective thermal conductivity enhancement ratios were 31% and 13% in the solid and liquid states when the mass fraction of the NAO was 10%. Li [34] reported that the thermal conductivity of the paraffin/NG composite was 7.41 times higher than that of the paraffin, when the mass fraction of the NG in the composite was 10%. There are a number of studies on nano–additives/PCM, such as metal nanoparticles [35,36], nano–CuO [37] and carbon nanotubes [38]. However, in the previous literatures, there are few reports on the FSPCM modified by the nano–additives for thermal conductivity enhancement [39,40]. It is meaningful to investigate the thermal enhancement on the FSPCM because PCM with stable shape can be employed in the practical application.
In order to adapt to various operating temperatures, the PCM with different phase change temperatures shall be applied in FSPCM based on the HDPE, and fatty acids and their eutectics may have choice of phase change temperature range. In this paper, one kind of fatty acids was absorbed into the HDPE, which was rarely mentioned in other researches. Meanwhile, the dense structure of the HDPE matrix makes it possible to employ the nano–additives for thermal conductivity enhancement because this dense structure can reduce the thermal contact resistance among the nano–materials, HDPE and PCM. The thermal contact resistance is resulted from interspace between the two interfaces. Two types of granular nano–additives are introduced into the MA/HDPE com-
posite to study the effects of thermal conductivities on the form– stable MA/HDPE composite.
The purpose of this work is to study the influences of the NAO and NG on the thermal behavior of the form–stable MA/HDPE composite as the FSPCM for latent heat energy storage. The MA is the main energy storage material and HDPE is used to prevent the leakage of the MA when the temperature is over the phase change temperature of the MA. The NG and NAO are added into the FSPCM to improve the thermal conductivity. A variety of measurements were conducted to investigate the microstructure, chemical structure, crystalline phase, thermal properties, thermal conductivity and thermal stability of the modified FSPCM. The result showed the significant enhancement on the thermal conductivity and thermal stability of the modified FSPCM, which could have extensive application prospect in thermal energy storage.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: MA (C14H28O2, tetradecane acid, Chemically Pure) was obtained from Qingdao Chemical technology Co., Ltd. HDPE (melt flow index: 20 g/10 min, density: 0.953 g/cm3, Vicat softening temperature: 126 C) was supplied by Dongguan Huangjiang Co., Ltd. NAO (particle diameter: 30–60 nm, purity: 99%) and NG (particle diameter: 10 nm, special surface area: >600 m2/g, purity: 99.9%) were provided by Nanjing XFNANO Materials Co., Ltd.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of the MA/HDPE composite
sections.text:
In order to increase the specific latent heat of the FSPCM, the maximum content of the MA should be confirmed firstly. To determine the maximum content of the MA, a series of the MA/HDPE
composites with MA contents of 60 wt% (HPCM1), 70 wt% (HPCM2), 80 wt% (HPCM3) and 90 wt% (HPCM4) were prepared using cantilevered mechanical agitator at a screw speed of 500 rpm for 30 min, and the operating temperature remained at 180 C, which is not more than the temperature at which MA decomposition begins (180 C). Fig. 1 shows the photographs of the HDPE, HPCM1–4 when the samples cooled down to room temperature. As seen from Fig. 1, the shapes of the HPCM1 and HPCM2 are stable and intact. However, the shapes of the HPCM3 and HPCM4 are loose and broken easily, which mainly results from the leakage of the MA. Therefore, 70 wt% can be considered to be the maximum content of the MA in the MA/HDPE composite without leakage, and the sample HPCM2 was selected to be the form– stable phase change material of the modified FSPCM.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of the modified FSPCM
sections.text:
In this work, the additives for thermal conductivity enhancement of the modified FSPCM were NAO and NG. Six kinds of modified FSPCM were prepared in different mass fractions of the NAO with 4% (CPCM1), 8% (CPCM2), 12% (CPCM3), and NG with 4% (CPCM4), 8% (CPCM5), 12% (CPCM6). Firstly, the additives were mixed uniformly with melted MA in water bath at 60 C and the blends were stirred by a magnetic stirrer at the rate of 1000 rpm for 30 min. Meanwhile, the HDPE was heated to 150 C in a stainless steel vessel. Finally, the preheated HDPE was mixed with the melted blends at 180 C using cantilevered mechanical agitator at the speed of 1000 rpm for 30 min. The compositions of the six samples were listed in Table 1. Fig. 2 shows the photographs of the CPCM1–CPCM6 at room temperature. The white samples were the FSPCM added by NAO while the black samples were the FSPCM added by NG. It can be confirmed that they all establish the form– stable structure.
yristic acid/high density polyethylene composites.

sections.heading: 2.4. Analysis methods
sections.text:
The chemical structures of the FSPCM were analyzed using a Fourier transformation infrared spectroscope (FT–IR, Nicolet Nexus 870, spectra range: 400–4000 cm 1). X–ray diffractometer (XRD, D/MAX–Ultima III, scanning rate: 5 (2h) min 1) was used to investigate the influence of the additives on the crystalloid phase of the FSPCM. A field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, ZEISS Ultra 55, Carl Zeiss, Germany) was used to characterize the morphology and microstructure of the samples, and the surfaces of samples were sputtered by gold to enhance surface electrical conductivity and prevent samples frommelting by intense electron beam. The specific latent heat and phase transition temperature of samples were determined by using a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC, Pyris 1 DSC, Perkin–Elmer, temperature accuracy: ±0.2 C, enthalpy accuracy: ±5%, heating rate: 5 C min 1) under a constant stream of argon and the temperature range is from 10 C to 180 C and took the average value of three repeated measurements. The thermal reliabilities of samples were tested by a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA, Pyris 1 TGA, Perkin–Elmer, heating rate: 20 C min 1) from 20 C to 700 C. The weight of experimental samples in all above tests is around 2.0 mg. The
shape of the tested samples is granular and the particle size is about 1.5 mm.
A thermal conductivity meter (TC 3020, Xiatech Electronic Technology co., Ltd, accuracy: ±2.0%) was used to measure the thermal conductivities of the FSPCM by using the hot–wire method. The setup for the measurement of thermal conductivity consists of a thermal conductivity meter and constant temperature water–bathing, which is showed in Fig. 3. The accuracy of constant temperature water–bathing is ±0.5 C. In order to determine the accuracy and reliability of the TC 3020, the Pyrex glass (Pyrex 7740) and stainless steel (304L) were used as referenced materials to calibrate the accuracy of the thermal conductivity meter. After being calibrated, the accuracy of the thermal conductivity meter (TC 3020) is ±2.0%. In order to reduce the thermal contact resistance between the samples and the hot–wire probe, the sample’s surface in contact with the hot–wire probe must be smooth. The prepared samples were melted at 160 C. Then they were poured into two watch–glasses equally and were divided into two similar pieces (diameter: 5 cm, thickness: 0.8 cm). The surfaces of samples needed to be polished with fine sandpaper to a glowing evenness at 30 C and 60 C respectively because the surface would change slightly with the change of temperature. Then, the hot– wire probe was inserted into the two smooth surfaces. The samples were placed in the constant temperature water–bathing and pressed with the weight to ensure close contact with the probe, as seen in Fig. 3. Thermal conductivity of each sample was measured repeatedly five times.

sections.heading: 3.1. FT-IR analysis
sections.text:
The chemical structures of the MA, HDPE, MA/HDPE composite, NAO, NG and CPCM1–CPCM6 are analyzed using the FT–IR spec-
nd nano–graphite/myristic acid/ high density polyethylene composites.
trum recorded from 400 cm 1 to 4000 cm 1 and they are shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4a identifies the FT–IR spectrum of the MA and the main absorption peaks will be explained below. The sharp absorption peaks at 2917 cm 1 and 2849 cm 1 are attributed to the antisymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of ACH2 group. The main peaks at 1701 cm 1, 1464 cm 1 and 941 cm 1 signify the C@O stretching vibration, ACH2 scissoring bending vibration and AOH out-of-plane wagging vibration, respectively. The peak at 719 cm 1 is assigned to the ACH2 rocking vibration only presented when 4 or more ACH2 groups in a chain. In Fig. 4b, the FT–IR spectrum of the HDPE have similar sharp absorption peaks at 2917 cm 1, 2849 cm 1, 1464 cm 1 and 719 cm 1 owing to the same chain of ACH2 groups. Therefore, the MA/HDPE composites
have the same FT–IR spectrum as MA, which are shown in Fig. 4c. In Fig. 4d, the plant absorption peaks at around 588 cm 1 and 440 cm 1 are responsible for AlAO vibration. There is no absorption peak in Fig. 4e because NG is symmetric molecules that have no dipole moment to resonate with radiation. The Fig. 4f–h shows two new absorption peaks at around 588 cm 1 and 440 cm 1 compared to the FT–IR spectrum of MA/HDPE composite, which indicates that the spectra of the FSCPM modified with NAO are superposed from the FSPCM and NAO. As seen in Fig. 4f–k, the FT-IR spectrum of the modified FSPCM indicates all the feature absorption peaks of the MA/HDPE composite, and no other peaks appear except the characteristic peaks of the AlAO vibration in Fig. 4f–h. The intensity of the characteristic absorption peak of
the MA/HDPE dropped with the loading of nano–powder, especially NG. In addition, there is no significant band shift compared to the MA/HDPE composites.
The results of the FT–IR analysis show that the FSPCM have been successfully modified with NAO and NG and there are no chemical reaction between the MA/HDPE composite and the additives.

sections.heading: 3.2. XRD analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 5 shows the XRD patterns of the MA, HDPE, MA/HDPE composite, NAO, NG and CPCM1–CPCM6. In Fig. 5a–c, there are two similar sharp diffraction peaks at about 21.6 and 23.9 , which
means that the MA/HDPE have formed the same crystal structure as MA and HDPE. Fig. 5d shows the several regular diffraction peaks of Al2O3 [41], and the XRD curve of the NG in Fig. 5e is similar to that of the expanded graphite [42]. Apparently, the sharp diffraction peak of the CPCM1–CPCM3 at 21.6 are stronger than that of CPCM4–CPCM6 by comparing Fig. 5f–h with Fig. 5i–k, which reveals that the crystalline region of the FSPCM modified by NAO is larger than that of the FSPCM modified by NG [43]. As seen in Fig. 5f–k, the two sharp peaks at about 21.6 and 23.9 are also observed in the XRD curves of the six modified FSPCM, which indicates that the additions of the NAO and NG have no influence on the crystal structure of the form–stable MA/HDPE composite.
f) CPCM1, (g) CPCM2, (h) CPCM3, (i) CPCM4, (j) CPCM5 and (k) CPCM6.
HPCM2, (c) CPCM2 and (d) CPCM5.

sections.heading: 3.3. Microstructure analysis
sections.text: The microstructures of the HDPE, MA/HDPE composite and modified FSPCM with NAO and NG are presented in Fig. 6. Fig. 6a shows the morphology of the HDPE. In Fig. 6b, the HDPE has formed a uniform net structure which wraps the particulates of the MA separately. It is the net structure of the HDPE that prevents the leakage of the MAwhen the MA is melted. Fig. 6c and d showed the microstructure images of the MA/HDPE/NAO andMA/HDPE/NG composites. As seen in Fig. 6c, the net structure can be observed clearly when the MA on the surface of the sample is melted by the electric beam from FESEM, and this structure still remains intact. Fig. 6d presents a more impact net structure. The FESEM result shows that the modified FSPCM had a form–stable structure supported by HDPE and formed impact net structure which can reduce the thermal contact resistance among the nano–materials, HDPE and MA.

sections.heading: 3.4. Specific latent heat and phase transition temperature of the modified FSPCM
sections.text:
The specific latent heat and phase transition temperature of the MA, HDPE and HPCM1–HPCM4 were described by the DSC curves in Figs. 7 and 8, and the relevant data are listed in Table 2. It is obvious that there are two peaks on the DSC curves of the MA/ HDPE composites. The first peak is caused by the solid–liquid phase change of the MA while the second peak is caused by the solid–liquid phase change of the HDPE. This is different from the eutectic phase change materials which only have one sharp peak [44], because no chemical bonds between the MA and HDPE have formed in the composite. As known from Table 2, the melting and solidifying temperature of the MA are 54.64 C and 52.26 C. The melting and solidifying temperature of the MA in HPCM2 are 53.80 C and 52.00 C which are very close to that of the pure MA. However, the specific latent heat of the HPCM (119 kJ/kg)
thylene and myristic acid/high density polyethylene composites.
yethylene and myristic acid/high density polyethylene composites.
decreases by comparison with that of the pure MA (193.80 kJ/kg), and the reason will be explained below.
The phase change of the MA is the method to store latent thermal energy in the FSPCM. Therefore, the value of melting and solidifying specific latent heat is proportional to the mass fraction of the MA in the MA/HDPE composites, and the relationship can be described by following:
DHC ¼ gDH0 ð1Þ
where DHC and DH0 are the melting and solidifying specific latent heat of the MA/HDPE composites and pure MA. g represents the mass fraction of the MA in the composites. As seen in Table 2, the melting and solidifying specific latent heat of the MA/HDPE decreases with the decreasing mass fraction of the MA, which can be predicted by Eq. (1). However, the experimental value of DHC is generally lower than the theoretic value. It may be caused by the decomposition of the MA when the mixture of the MA and HDPE was operated at 180 C.Figs. 9, 10 and Table 3 reveal the specific latent heat and phase transition temperature of the modified FSPCM. The melting temperature of the CPCM1–CPCM6 are

Fig. 11. TGA curves of the myristic acid, high density polyethyle
53.32 C, 53.56 C, 53.46 C, 53.17 C, 53.02 C and 52.89 C, respectively. The specific latent heat of CPCM1–CPCM6 decreased slightly with the increasing content of the NAO and NG, which can also be explained by Eq. (1). Therefore, the content of the additive should be limited for maintaining high specific latent heat.
It’s worth noting that the melting specific latent heat is larger than the solidifying specific latent heat. Jin et al. [45] found that the enthalpy and the state of the PCM were not only dependent on its temperature, but also were affected by its ‘‘previous state” – or rather, the supercooling. As showed in Figs. 8 and 10, there is more than one peak in the solidifying DSC curves, especially in CPCM4–6 DSC curves. The PCM with serious supercooling even has no peaks in solidifying DSC curves [45]. The DSC curve may appear flat lines in the partial solidifying processes. As a result, the range from low temperature and high temperature for specific latent heat calculation is less than the true range, and the calculated solidifying specific latent heat is not the whole solidifying specific latent heat.
As seen in Tables 2 and 3, the phase transition temperatures of both MA and HDPE in the mixtures are lower than those of pure substances. The reason may be expressed by the entropy formula:
t ¼ dQ dS
ð2Þ
where t is the phase transition temperatures of the MA or HDPE. dQ is the melting and solidifying heat change per unit mass. dS is the entropy change. In the mixtures, the entropy of the MA or HDPE will become larger than that in pure substances. Meanwhile, there is no indication that the melting and solidifying heat change increase. Therefore, the phase transition temperatures of both MA and HDPE in the mixtures will become lower. In general, the modified FSPCM still have the advantages of stable transformation temperature and high specific latent heat for thermal energy storage.

sections.heading: 3.5. Thermal reliability of the modified FSPCM
sections.text:
The thermal reliabilities of the MA, HDPE, HPCM1–HPCM4 and CPCM1–CPCM are illustrated by the TGA and DTG curves in Figs. 11–14. According to the DTG curves, the temperatures (tpeak) of maximum thermal degradation rate and the corresponding percentage (DW) of the mass loss are listed in Table 4. The tpeak of the
ne and myristic acid/high density polyethylene composites.
pure MA and HDPE are 254.92 C and 501.54 C, respectively. Two tpeak are showed in the DTG curves of the HPCM1–HPCM4 and CPCM1–CPCM6. The first tpeak represents the thermal degradation temperature of the MA in the composites. The weight loss of the MA begins at around 180 C and the MA completely loses weight at about 300 C. The second tpeak represents the thermal degradation temperature of the HDPE, and the weight loss of HDPE takes place between about 450 C and 550 C. Apparently, the tpeak of the MA in HPCM1–HPCM4 is similar to that of the pure MA, which means the reliability of the MA/HDPE composite is not decreased by the HDPE as supporting materials. The tpeak of the MA in CPCM1–CPCM6 are very close to that of the MA in the MA/HDPE composite. Hence, the additions of NAO and NG have no influence on the reliability of the modified FSPCM. In addition, theDW1 andDW2 are roughly consistence with the percent content of the
MA and HDPE in the composites, which indicates that the MA and HDPE are intensively mixed.

sections.heading: 3.6. Thermal conductivity of the modified FSPCM
sections.text:
The main purpose of this work is to enhance the thermal conductivity of the form–stable MA/HDPE composite PCM for improving the storage and release rate of thermal energy by the additions of the NAO and NG. The thermal conductivities of the HPCM2 and CPCM1–CPCM6 were tested at 30 C (Fig. 15) and 60 C (Fig. 16), corresponding to the solidifying and melting state of the MA in the modified FSPCM, respectively. The values are listed in Table 5. The thermal conductivities of the HPCM2 with 70 wt% of the HDPE are 0.2038W (m K) 1 (30 C) and 0.1918W (m K) 1 (60 C). As seen from Figs. 15 and 16, the thermal conductivities of the

Samples tpeak1 ( C) DW1 (%) tpeak2 ( C) DW2 (%)
MA 254.92 ± 5.09 100.0 HDPE 501.54 ± 10.03 100.0 HPCM1 (60% MA) 244.23 ± 4.88 61.9 492.91 ± 9.85 38.1 HPCM2 (70% MA) 249.47 ± 4.98 67.6 499.97 ± 9.99 32.4 HPCM3 (80% MA) 254.39 ± 5.08 80.2 497.43 ± 9.94 19.8 HPCM4 (90% MA) 256.03 ± 5.12 92.2 495.57 ± 9.91 7.8 CPCM1 (4% NAO) 259.36 ± 5.18 68.4 501.69 ± 10.03 29.7 CPCM2 (8% NAO) 249.65 ± 4.99 65.7 499.71 ± 9.99 29.0 CPCM3 (12% NAO) 244.88 ± 4.89 63.6 476.57 ± 9.53 24.4 CPCM4 (4% NG) 251.87 ± 5.03 68.1 500.31 ± 10.00 30.1 CPCM5 (8% NG) 254.54 ± 5.09 65.0 503.94 ± 10.07 29.5 CPCM6 (12% NG) 245.08 ± 4.90 66.6 501.74 ± 10.03 23.7
Fig. 15. Thermal conductivities of myristic acid/high density polyethylene composite (70 at 30 C in solid state of the MA.
CPCM1–CPCM6 are almost directly proportional to the content of the NAO and NG in the modified FSPCM. When the mass fractions of the NAO and NG are 12%, the thermal conductivity of the FSPCM increases from 0.2038W (m K) 1 to 0.3972W (m K) 1 and 0.4503W (m K) 1 at 30 C respectively. Generally, the addition of the NG has a stronger enhancement effect on the thermal conductivity, than that of addition of the NAO.
The accurate relationship between thermal conductivity of the modified FSPCM and the content of the NAO and NG can be described by the polynomial fitting of the experimental values. The result is displayed in Figs. 15 and 16 and the fitting equations are expressed as following:
k1 ¼ 0:2076þ 2:93x1 7:8x21 ð3Þ
k2 ¼ 0:2039þ 2:20x2 4:9x22 ð4Þ
% myristic acid) with different mass fractions of the nano–Al2O3 and nano–graphite
k4 ¼ 0:1931þ 0:9x2 þ 2:9x22 ð6Þ where x1 and x2 are the mass fractions of the NG and NAO. k1 and k2 are the thermal conductivities of the modified FSPCM at 30 C. k3 and k4 are the thermal conductivities of the modified FSPCM at 60 C. The correlation coefficients of the Eqs. (3)–(6) are all more than 0.96. When x1 and x2 are lower than 0.1, the quadratic term of Eqs. (3)–(6) can be ignored. Under this circumstance, the thermal conductivity of the modified FSPCM has approximately linear relationship with the content of the NAO and NG. Moreover, the quadratic term coefficients of Eqs. (3)–(6) are mainly negative within the margin of error, which reveals that the effect of the nano–additives on the thermal conductivity enhancement of the modified FSPCM will decrease with the increasing content of the nano–additives. This phenomenon may be resulted from the insufficient dispersion.
Several theoretical and empirical models based on physical principles are used to predict the thermal conductivity of composites [46]. Harish et al. [47,48] developed a modified effective medium theory (EMT) model to analyze the experimental values. However, the calculated thermal conductivity of the EMT model is highly sensitive to the thermal interface resistance and the particle aspect ratio more than the thermal conductivity of particle itself. In consideration of negative quadratic term coefficients in Eqs. (3)–(6), the physics–based model does not accord with the experimental thermal conductivity in this work.
Table 6 shows the thermal conductivities of the PCM modified by the NAO and NG in previous works for comparison with that of the modified FSPCM. The nano–additives in Table 6 are same as this work, but the PCM composites had not been developed stable form in previous researches. And there are very few literatures on the thermal conductivity enhancement of the FSPCM by adding nano–additives on account of the usual porous matrixes in the FSPCM. The thermal conductivity in this work is slightly less than that in previous researches because the thermal contact resistance among the nano–materials, HDPE and MA can’t be ignored absolutely although the structure of the HDPE matrix is dense. But it can be confirmed that the modified FSPCM obtains well thermal conductivity enhancement for practical application in this work.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
A series of form–stable MA/HDPE composites modified by the addition of NAO and NG were prepared in this work. In the modified FSPCM, the MA was used as a solid–liquid PCM, the high density polyethylene (HDPE) acted as supporting material to prevent the leakage of the melted MA, and the NAO and NG were additives for thermal conductivity enhancement. The FESEM result shows the HDPE has formed a uniform net structure to prevent leakage of the MA during the melting process and the maximummass fraction of the MA in FSPCM is 70%, and the modified FSPCM formed impact net structure which makes it possible to employ the nano–additives for thermal conductivity enhancement. The specific latent heat and melting temperature of the FSPCM with 70%
MA are 159.08 kJ/kg and 53.74 C, respectively. The modified FSPCM have constant melting temperature (about 53 C), high specific latent heat (at least 88.00 kJ/kg) and good thermal reliability. The operating temperature of the FSPCM is less than 180 C at which the MA begins to decompose. The thermal conductivity of the FSPCM can increase from 0.2038W (m K) 1 to 0.3972W (m K) 1 (NAO) and 0.4503W (m K) 1 (NG) at 30 C when the mass fraction of nano–additives is 12%. And at 60 C, the value can increase from 0.1918W (m K) 1 to 0.3471W (m K) 1 (NAO) and 0.3923W (m K) 1 (NG). Generally, the thermal conductivity of the FSPCM with the NG is larger than that of the FSPCM with the NAO in the same mass ratio. The relationship between the thermal conductivities of modified FSPCM and content of the NAO and the NG was found to be almost directly proportional. However, it seems that the effect of the nano–additives on the thermal conductivity enhancement of the modified FSPCM will decrease with the increasing content of the nano–additives. Therefore, the mass fraction of nano–additives is better to be controlled within 10%. This phenomenon may be resulted from the insufficient dispersion, which can’t be observed by FESEM in this work. Overall, the modified FSPCM with stable shape, enhanced thermal conductivity, high specific latent heat, good thermal reliability and chemical stability are promising alternative materials for practical application.

referenceMentions.context: Therefore, these systems will use less energy during peak time, which can improve system’s efficiency, such as building heat preservation [1–3] and solar water heat [4], which are usually time dependent.
The thermal energy storage system can store and release energy in the forms of sensible heat, latent heat and reversible thermochemical reaction for energy redistribution [5].
In addition, the temperature of the PCM remains almost the same not only during phase change process but also from storage to release [6].
The PCM involves four states of phase change: solid–solid, solid–liquid, gas–solid and gas–liquid [7].
solid–liquid variety can be used for practical application because the other varieties have technical limitation [8].
The solid–liquid PCM is usually categorized into organic PCM, inorganic PCM and their eutectics [9].

In recent decades, a variety of fatty acids belonging to organic PCMwere investigated and used for practical application [10–12] because they are economically affordable and wildly available, non–toxic and have low subcooling degree [13].
This will result in the increase of thermal resistance and associated cost [14].
In recent years, developing micro–encapsulated phase change material (MEPCM) and form–stable phase change materials (FSPCM) is a popular solution to overcome the defect above [15,16].
In recent years, developing micro–encapsulated phase change material (MEPCM) and form–stable phase change materials (FSPCM) is a popular solution to overcome the defect above [15,16].

High volume change, large supercooling, complicated synthesis technology and high cost of the MEPCM are primary limiting factors for its thermal energy storage application in comparison with the FSPCM, although the MEPCM can encapsulate the organic PCM and increase the thermal transfer area [17].

metadata.abstractText: For the purpose of improving the thermal conductivity of the form–stable phase change materials (FSPCM), two types of nano–powders with high thermal conductivity were added into the samples. In the modified FSPCM, myristic acid (MA) was used as a solid–liquid phase change material (PCM), high density polyethylene (HDPE) acted as supporting material to prevent the leakage of the melted MA. Nano–Al2O3 (NAO) and nano–graphite (NG) were the additives for thermal conductivity enhancement. Scanning electronic microscope (SEM), Fourier transformation infrared spectroscope (FT–IR) and X-ray diffractometer (XRD) were used to analyze the microstructure, chemical structure and crystalline phase of the samples, respectively. Furthermore, the specific latent heat and phase transition temperature, thermal conductivity and thermal reliability were investigated using differential scanning calorimeter (DSC), thermal conductivity meter and thermo–gravimetric analyzer (TGA). The results showed that the MA was uniformly absorbed in the HDPE matrices and there was no leakage during the melting process when the mass fraction of the MA in the MA/HDPE composite was less than 70%. The DSC results revealed that the modified FSPCM have a constant phase change temperature and high specific latent heat. The thermal conductivity of the FSPCM was measured in the solid (30 C) and liquid (60 C) states of the MA. When the mass fraction of nano–powder additives is 12%, the thermal conductivities of the FSPCM increase by 95% (NAO) and 121% (NG) at 30 C. It is anticipated that the FSPCM possess a potential application for thermal energy storage. 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
